title: Preface
text:
This year’s report covers the years 2010 to 2020 and provide descriptive statistics for the following categories; artisanal fisheries total landings; artisanal catch rates; artisanal fisheries catch weight, number of fishing caught, number of fishers, catch rates and price trends. The report also provides management highlights for each district that include summary of stock status, updates on catch rates; trend of total landings; and other management schemes in the area like existance of collaborative fisheries management areas.
Information in this report came from several sources. Artisanal landings, revenue, and prive data were primarily obtained from the Fisheries Statistics Division, Office of the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries. Records from the ministry encompass catch records of analog data storage system called Catch Assessment Survey (CAS); electronic Catch Assement Survey (e-CAS) and frame surveys obtained from the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, Fisheries Division. We also obtained catch related data of the Mafia Island from the Mafia Island Marine Protected Areas. Spatial data that illustrate the locations of collaborative fisheries management areas (CFMA) were obtained from WWF-Tanzania. Critical coastal habitats like mangroves, seagrass and coral reefs spatial datasets were collected from the archives of the Institute of Marine Sciences.
The purpose of this assignment is to provide a resource that will help fisheries managers and decision makers in the coastal and marine waters of Tanzania to quickly identify potential and sustainable coastal areas for fisheries. The report was developed so that it can be easily used by anyone involved in fisheries and coastal resource management, regardless of the water body or project scope. This report explains:

The state of the e-CAS database
How the data included in the report was gathered and analysed
How the indicators were selected and parameters computed
How to use the report

The report also include case studies that illustrate some of the collaborative fisheries management areas that clearly indicate fishing good practises for sustainable resources use.

title: 1  Management Context
text:
The authority to manage coastal and marine fisheries in Tanzania is legally under the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries. The marine fisheries in Tanzania is dominated by small scale artisanal fisheries that constitute more than 90 percent of the total landed weights. The Tanzania Fisheries Research Institute (TAFIRI) is the public institute with delegated authority from the ministry to conduct research of fisheries and related field in the freshwater and marine waters of Tanzania. The fisheries of Tanzania are generally defined as fishing activities that take place in the United Republic of territorial and Exclusive Economic Zones—up to 200 nautical miles from it’s coastline. WWF-Tanzania is actively collaborating with public agencies to ensure fisheries resources are utilized and sustained for future generations.
In 2018, TAFIRI in collaboration with WWF conducted a pilot study to explore the use of the mobile application as a tool in fisheries data collection (Sailale & Mpuruti, 2021). The initiative started with five selected villages and members from village’s BMU were trained to use an application to record fisheries data in the electronic Catch Assessment Survey (e-CAS). Through this initiative several species of tuna and tuna-like were recorded for the first time (Kuguru and Sailale, 2018). Following the benefits of the e-CAS, the Government of Tanzania adopted the platform and endorsed as tool for fisheries data collection both in coastal and marine waters. Later, the East African Community (EAC) through Lake Victoria Fisheries Organization (LVFO) Secretariat approved the use of e–CAS to collect and manage fisheries resources in the area.
Today, amount of fisheries data that exists in the e–CAS are enough to assist scientist to evaluate and explore the fisheries dynamics in both coastal and freshwater ecosystems. Recognizing the archived fisheries data, early 2019 WWF TCO/WWF UK requested TAFIRI to assess fisheries performance in coastal areas that receive WWF’s support and compare the findings with coastal areas without WWF’s support. Early 2020, WWF TCO through the support of Blue Action Fund (BAF) commissioned a consultancy work to TAFIRI to extend the analysis and of fisheries in the e-CAS that was collected between 2017 and 2020.
BAF aims to strengthen small scale fisheries management of three priority groups—octopus, small pelagic and prawn in the Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa seascape. Given the size of the area, BAF strategically chose ten collaborative fisheries managed areas (CFMAs) that bring together 42 villages that intersect with the proposed Man and Biosphere Reserve. BAF focus on monitoring fisheries resources in the area and ensure sustainable utilization of fisheries and its related resources. The project prime goal is to determine biological and exploitation fisheries reference points that can be used as indicators to gauge the state of fisheries in the area.
Though the e–CAS has archieved a substantial amount of artisal fish records, however, these data are fishery dependent and lack important measurements like total length and weight along with maturity stage of individual fish. These three measurements are key to assess the stock of data poor fishery like those in the Kibiti, Mafia, and Kilwa Seascape. With additional data collected through SWIOFISH project, the data in e–CAS can suffice to assess the stock of some species and serve as reference points for fisheries exploitation in the future.

title: 1  Management Context
text:
1.1 Scope of the Assignment
This assignment intends to improve the accuracy of the artisanal fisheries catch data that has been collected through an electronic Catch Assessment Survey (e–CAS). The information generated through this study will assist fisheries managers and decision makers to plan and allocate resources for strategic intervations that are based on scientific findings. Furthermore, the assignment explored the strength and weakness of the platform and identify gaps that need to be addressed in order to refine and produce a quality report in the future.

title: 1  Management Context
text:
1.2 Objectives
The overall objective of this assignment was use archived fisheries catch data in e–CAS, analyse them and reports of the fishery state in Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa coastal area. Understanding that will help to improve the accuracy of the artisanal fisheries catch data to better inform policy and decision making for improved management of small-scale fisheries resources in the RUMAKI seascape. More specifically, the specific objectives were:

Provide clear definition of the research guiding questions for undertaking the study based on the assigned TORs.
Analyse quality of the available e-CAS data for priority fisheries and other fisheries from ten (10) CFMAs landing sites in Rufiji/Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa.
Determine spatial distribution of priority fisheries and fishing effort in the project area
Undertake comparison of catch per unit effort (CPUE) and total production in the project area (Rufiji, Mafia and Kilwa Districts) per district from 2010 – 2018 as a baseline reference point.
Using historical fisheries data from MIMP (2010-2018) to analyse CPUE, species composition and fish production trends of priority fisheries (CAS in MIMP 2010-2018; e-CAS 2017-2020, CAS from fisheries data base (2010-2015) in Rufiji, Mafia and Kilwa districts)
Define a simple and replicable indicator and baseline on the sustainability of 3 priority fisheries (Small Pelagics, Prawn and Octopus) focusing on the CFMAs in the districts of Mafia, Kibiti and Kilwa (e.g. CPUE, total production), based on available data.
Develop data driven tools to complement existing statistical system and recommend on how to improve;
Prepare a policy brief in close collaboration with WWF marine programme staff based on analysed information to inform decision-makers and stakeholders about the status and sustainability of fisheries in Rufiji-Mafia-Kilwa seascape

title: 2  Key Concepts
text: To guide its efforts, the research team defined the concept like fish, fish catch, catch rates,and total landings, to establish indicators (parameters) of this consultancy. The following chapter discuss how these terms were selected and and applied for this research project.

title: 2  Key Concepts
text:
2.1 Fish
Fish are a renewable and mobile natural resource. Aside from aquaculture farming, fish are generally not owned until they have been caught. As such, fish stocks continue to be regarded as a common resource which needs to be managed collectively. This has led to a range of policies that regulate the amount of fishing at the EU level and more widely at sea basin level, as well as the types of fishing techniques and gear that can be used in fish capture.

title: 2  Key Concepts
text:
2.2 Fisher
Wikipedia define a fisher as a person who catches fish for a living or for sport Wikipedia contributors (2022).

title: 2  Key Concepts
2  Key Concepts
text:
2.4 Capture fishery
Capture fishery refers to all kinds of harvesting of naturally occurring living resources in both marine and freshwater environments. On a broad level, capture fisheries can be classified as industrial, small-scale/artisanal and recreational. A more specific level includes reference to the fishing area, gear and the main target species, such as the small pelagic fishery, Rufiji Delta shrimp trawl fishery, deep water tuna longline fishery in the Exclusive Economic Zones.

title: 2  Key Concepts
text:
2.5 Catch Rates
Catch rate, or the estimated number of fish caught per angler trip, is determined using data collected during a fishing trip. Fish catch (or simply catch) refers to catches of fishery products including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and other aquatic animals, residues and aquatic plants, that are taken at from the fishing ground in specified time.
Catch rate has been defined as differently by several institutes and individuals. Because each fisheries officer, goverment agency and non-goverment organizations will have different definitions or criteria for determining what they consider as catch rates based on the available data and the type of fishery, the research team has taken a broader approach to identify catch rates.
The essence of catch rates is to standardized the landed weight. Standardization is essential, in any observational dataset, to allow undistorted comparisons of rates over time or over different areas. In fisheries, commercial catch rates are often standardized for use as an index of relative abundance, particularly in fisheries where a regular resource survey has not been feasible (Hilborn and Walters, 1992; Maunder and Punt, 2004).
To be useful as an index of relative abundance, raw catch per unit effort (cpue) must be standardized for changes or variations in catchability, or changes in cpue that are attributable to variable catchability may be incorrectly concluded to be due to changes in abundance.

title: 2  Key Concepts
text:
2.6 Fishing Effort
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations defined fishing effort as the time spent searching for fish (search duration) and/or the amount of fishing gear of a specific type used on the fishing grounds over a given unit of time e.g. a fishing operation, fishing activity, day or fishing trip. The measure of effort (unit of fishing effort) depends on the fishery and type of gear used. The impact of a unit of fishing effort on the fish populations and the ecosystem in general differs among vessels and fishers and depends on the gear deployed.
Species A group of similar organisms that can freely interbreed
Population A group of individuals of the same species living in a certain area
Stock A harvested or managed unit of fish- can be separated by geographical boundaries. Sometimes, more than one species is included in stock as they are harvested together as though they are one species

title: 3  Method
text:
3.2 Study Area
The Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa Seascape (See Figure 3.1) is a shallow coastal areas of the Tanzania’s mainland where coastal fisheries provide an important livelihood and the primary source of dietary animal protein in rural areas. The ecological functioning of this seascape provide food, income and tourism industry (Tumbo et al., 2015).This seascape is the most biologically productive and diverse marine area in Tanzania and East Africa. According to Oglethorpe (n.d.), this seascape cover about 25 percent of the Tanzanian mainland’s nearshore waters and supports a myriad of marine fish catches. About 26 percent of coral reef habitats is found in this seascape and and a largest mangrove cover (See Figure 3.2) in the Western Indian Ocean Region.
The change of these monsoon winds have strong influence on the oceanographic conditions and weather patterns in the area thus also affects marine fisheries ecology and production. Furthermore, the discharge of Rufiji River into the area has continuously mix salt water the freshwater from mainland and creates a unique and largest estuary in the region. Together with The presence of critical coastal habitats—mangroves, seagrass and coral reefs in the Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa seascape serve as nursery and feeding grounds thus make it one of the most productive coastal area in Tanzania.

title: 3  Method
text:
3.3 Weather and Climate
The weather and climate of coastal districts of Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa is generally similar and influenced by prevailing trade winds. These winds tend to reverse and form two alternating monsoon seasons (Richmond, 1995; Semba et al., 2019). The northeast monsoon (NEM) season is warm, hot, rainy and weak wind speed that blow from northeast direction. The NEM often occurs from November through March. In contrast, the southeast monsoon season characteristic mirror the NEM. SEM is cool, dry and strong wind speed that prevail from the southeast. The SEM last for six months and often begin early October and end in May.

title: 3  Method
text:
3.4 Fisheries Data
To develop the most comprehensive data analytical tool for fisheries management in Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa Districts several sources were identified and consulted. The research team began with a review of published literature on the seascape to build the collection of documented fisheries issues in the area and gather necessary information. Next, existing collaborative fisheries management areas were identified. Then mobile calls were conducted to identify unpublished fisheries management initiatives in the areas or practises that are in development. The calls also were used to identify which CFMA have implemented sustainable fisheries management practices including collection of fisheries and fisheries related data and seek information of any positive or negative benefits that establishment of the CFMA brought to them. The data collection phases and their results are discussed in this chapter.
The study used existing and historical marine fishery. small scale fisheries landings, revenue, and price data, and recreational fishing effort and participation data, were primarily obtained from the Fisheries Statistics Division of the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries; Mafia Island Marine Park (MIMP) and Tanzania Fisheries Research Institute. Other data sources included the WWF-Tanzania that provided data of designated as collaborative fisheries management areas (CFMA). The spatial data of coastal habitats like mangroves, seagrasses and coral reef areas was obtained from the Institute of Marine Sciences of the University of Dar es salaam. Fishing-related economics and sociocultural information was obtained from the National Bureau of Statistics.

title: 3  Method
text:
3.5 Landing sites
The 2018 frame survey reported more than 250 landing sites are found along the coastline of Tanzania’s mainland (Sailale & Mpuruti, 2021). About 106 of these landing sites record the fish catch and related information into the electronic catch assessment survey (e–CAS) platform. Seventy nine of these landing sites are found in coastal waters of Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa with more than 75 percent engaged in data entry of daily fish catches into the e–CAS (Sailale & Mpuruti, 2021).

3.5.1 Catch and Effort Data
Catch assessment and frame surveys are the techniques widely used to collect fisheries catch and effort information. The Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries (MLF) of Tanzania mainland has been collecting both catch and effort data for decades using conventional method. However, Sailale & Mpuruti (2021) reported that the ministry adopted an electronic data collection system in 2016 to collect and store fisheries data.
The ministry has been collecting catch information that is used to assess the stock status of marine fisheries in a modern technique since 2017 (Sailale & Mpuruti, 2021). According to Sailale and Mpuruti (2021), the electronic catch assessment survey (eCAS), which replaced manual data collection (CAS), has revolutionized data collection, storage and retrieval of fisheries in Tanzania mainland. The eCAS system provide real-time fisheries data of 106 landing sites along seventeen coastal districts of Tanzania since July 2017 up to date. The system records almost ten days information of catches data that a spread in a month (Sailale & Mpuruti, 2021). The ministry selected enumerators from representative landing sites, who records catches landed at the landing sites and enter the recorded information into the eCAS system using mobile phones. The catch fishery data at the landing sites include;

administrative information — name of the landing site, village and district.
the geographical information(longitude and latitude) and time stemp of data entry
fishing grounds and collaborative fisheries management areas (CFMA)
type of vessels and its mode of propulsion
type, size and number of gears
number of fishers in a vessel
the departure and return time of fishing
weight and number of individual species landed
active fishing days



3.5.2 Collaborative fisheries management areas
The geometry polygon shapefiles of collaborative fisheries management areas(CFMA) within the RUMAKI seascape will be gathered from the WWF-Tanzania Office. These spatial data contain the boundary of the CFMA along with the corresponding name of each CFMA.


3.5.3 Mafia Island Marine Park
The Mafia Island Marine Park (MIMP) collects fishery dependent catch and effort data of the landing sites that fall within the park. The initiatives have been collecting catch and economic data of several species since 2010. The data include……


3.5.4 Frame Survey
The second dataset of fisheries that provide effort information at selected landing sites comes from frame surveys. Although the ministry have conducted a biannual frame survey for sometime, only a database of frame surveys for 2016 and 2018 are available in digital forms. Effort information for previous years will be extracted from annual fisheries reports.


3.5.5 Fishing Grounds
The areas in water that fishers go fishing are called fishing grounds and these are important in fisheries. Knowing the geographical position (longitude and latitude) of fishing grounds help management of fisheries, because they provide critical information where fishers prefer to harvest the resources. Recognizing the importance of the geographical positions, TAFIRI established a participatory approach in which fishers record and mark the positions of daily fishing events at particular fishing ground. Although these information is available for all coastal districts of Tanzania mainland and Zanzibar, it only provide a snapshot of common fishing grounds because it was focused for ringnet fishery and covered six months period of data collection. In this work, we will use these information to supplement CFMAs fishing grounds.

title: 3  Method
text:
3.6 Data analysis and processing

3.6.1 Data processing
Landing sites were grouped according to management schemes. Depending on the location of the landing site, they were intersected with the collaborative fisheries management areas (CFMAs). Those that fall within the CFMAs were grouped into management scheme and those outside the CFMAs as non-management scheme.


3.6.2 Seasonality
To assess the effect of monsoon seasons, fisheries, satellites and meteorological data will be categorized into two monsoon seasons. Data with time stamp from May to October wlll be placed in the Southeast monsoon season (SEM) and records that are within a period from November to April will be placed into the northeast monsoon season (NEM)


3.6.3 Priority fisheries
Fish were grouped into three major priority fishery groups. These groups are prawn, octopus and small pelagics.


3.6.4 Catch rate (Catch Per Unit Effort)
To reduce variation in weight of landed catches at each geographical location of harvestable areas, the e–CAS fisheries catch data were standardized and catch rates defined as catch per unit effort (CPUE) was derived. This was particularly important for further analysis of assessing fish stock healthiness. Catch rate of individual reported landing was obtained by dividing the total weight obtained in a catch of each fishing trip by number of fishers in a vessel and obtain CPUE in units of kilograms per fishers as outlined in equation @ref(eq:cpue1).
\[\begin{equation}
\bar{CPUE} = \frac{\sum_{n = \infty}^{\infty} W_{i}^j}{N_{i}^j} (\#eq:cpue1)
\end{equation}\]
Where \(W\) is the weight in kilogram and \(N\) is the number of fishers in a vessel at that fished at geographical location \(i\) from a particular vessels \(j\)


3.6.5 Spatial Feature of fishing grounds
Since e–CAS catch data lack geographical positions of fishing grounds, these information will be extracted from ringnet data, which contain geographical information of fishing grounds along the coastal waters of mainland Tanzania and Zanzibar.Once the spatial information is obtained, will be joined with e–Cas data using common variable— fishing ground name.

title: 3  Method
text:
3.7 Software and Tools
All data preparations, analysis and plotting results and writing of detailed methodology was carried out in R language (R Core Team, 2020). We chose R language as an analytical platform because is an open source, which is free and its scripts can be shared. Several packages were used to analyse, plot and write this report. Some for loading data like readr (Wickham & Hester, 2020) package for reading comma–separated files, readxl for Excel spreadsheets (Wickham & Bryan, 2019), and ncdf4 (Pierce, 2019) for importing satellite data stored in NECDF file format and sf (Pebesma, 2018) package for loading shapefile and simple feature files.
Other package like dplyr (Wickham et al., 2021) for manipulating data, tidyr (Wickham, 2021) for organizing the file into a consistent format for subsequent analysis and mapping, and lubridate (Grolemund & Wickham, 2011) for dealing with date and monsoon season. wior package by Semba & Peter (2020), will be used to detect outlier observation from dataset. The results from analysis will be summarized and presented in tables with knitr (Xie, 2014) and kableExtra (Zhu, 2021) packages while plotting and mapping will be accomplished using a combination of ggplot2 (Wickham, 2016) and metR (Campitelli, 2021) packages.
This detailed methodology was written using bookdown (Xie, 2016) and rmarkdown(Xie et al., 2020) packages and the the script that contains functions used to process, analyse, plot and map results can be accessed here.

title: 4  Spatial distribution of priority fisheries and fishing effort
text:
One of the most basic issues that is important for fisheries management is the understanding of the the distribution of key indicators and whether they change both in space and time. The common approach that is widely used in fisheries management is taking statistics at the receiving hand—landing sites. The central problem is that doing that only provide reference of the catch at the receiving hand—landing sites and ignore the source of fishery resource—fishing grounds. In this chapter we discuss catch rates, income and fishing effort at the collaborative fisheries managed areas (CFMA) and compare how they vary both in space and time.
The Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa seascape (Figure 4.1) is a unique coastal areas because of myriad coastal habitats like magroves, seagrass and coral reefs, discharge of Rufiji River that form the largest estuary in the region, the change of speed and direction of trade winds that form monsoon winds, and the bathing of the East African Coastal Current that mix the water continuously.

The records in the e-CAS vary not only by the priority fishery but also for the collaborative fisheries managed areas (CFMAs). For instance, Figure 4.2 illustrated the reef fishery records constitute more than 62 percent and most of these records are from the Nyamanjisopoja CFMA. The small pelagic fishery constitute about 16 percent of the total records and like reef fish, most records are from Nyamanjisopoja CFMA (Figure 4.2). Other priority fishery are distributed across CFMAs at small proportions.





Figure 4.2: The percentage composition of priority fishery by CFMAs based on the avaialble e-CAS dataset




Though octopus and prawns are among important fisheries in the area, but their records in the e-CAS are few. For instance, we found that Octopus fishery is most recorded at BK CFMA and no single value of octopus has been recorded in CFMAS like Nyamanjisopoja (Figure 4.3), which has the highest records of Reef and small pelagic fishery. The absent of octopus fishery in other CFMA suggest that records in the e-CAS is fishery priority specific.





Figure 4.3: The percentage composition for octopus, small pelagic and reef fishery by CFMAs based on the avaialble e-CAS dataset










Figure 4.4: The percentage composition for octopus, small pelagic and reef fishery by CFMAs based on the avaialble e-CAS dataset









The fisheries governance framework in Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa seascape is centred around the establishment of collaborative fisheries management areas (CFMAs). CFMAs are jointly managed by neighbouring BMUs who share fishing grounds. Among many key objectives of CFMA include conducting fishing pattern surveys and identifying priority fisheries. A functioning CFMA usually has BMU Statistics Committee capable to collect and analyse fisheries data for internal decision making. They are familiar with types and uses of fisheries data and guided through the process of designing and reviewing a data collection protocol.
Reporting of fisheries data in the electronic catch assessment system often depend on the collaboration with beach management unit (BMU). The willingness of BMU in a particular CFMA is key for successful data entry. We found that data entry into the e-CAS system relate closely to the BMU operations and data vary accordingly. For instance, more than 88 percent of data in Kibiti recorded fished at Mchimchunya CFMA (Figure 4.5). title: 5  Baseline Reference Points
text:
The goal of fishery management is to determine how many (numbers) or how much (weight) fish can be safely harvested from a stock. Or how many fish in a stock can die and still allow the stock to maintain itself. The rate at which fish die refers as mortality or the mortality rate.
Each year some fish die whether they are harvested or not.The rate at which fish die of natural causes is called natural mortality and the rate at which fish die from fishing is called fishing mortality. Often times the biological and exploitation reference points are used to inform management that state of the fishery resource. Some of the information needed to understand the stock of the fishery are includes;

title: 5  Baseline Reference Points
text:
5.1 Information about fishery

The kinds of fishermen in the fishery (trawlers, longliners, gillnetters, etc.).
Quantity of fish caught by each kind of fisherman over many years.
Fishing effort expended by each kind of fisherman over many years.
The age structure of the fish caught by each group of fishermen.
The ratio males to females in the catch.
How the fish are marketed (preferred size, etc.).
The value of fish to the different groups of fishermen.
The time and geographic area of best catches.

title: 5  Baseline Reference Points
text:
5.2 Information about biology

The age structure of the stock.
The age at first spawning.
Fecundity (average number of eggs each age fish can produce).
Ratio of males to females in the stock.
Natural mortality (the rate at which fish die of natural causes).
Fishing mortality (the rate at which fish die of being harvested).
Growth rate of the fish.
Spawning behavior (time and place).
Habitats of recently hatched fish (larvae), of juveniles and of adults.
Migratory habits.
Food habits for all ages of fish in the stock.
Estimate of the total number or weight of fish in the stock

To estimate the stock of fishery, we ought to have biometric information—length, weight, and maturity stage of individual fish. Since e-CAS rely on fishery dependent information, this information is not collected. Fortunately, during the SWIOFP and SWIOFISH projects, some biometric data were collected. In this chapter we discuss biological and exploitation parameters of prawn fishery. We compare these parameters for 2011 and 2020, for which data is available.

title: 6  Indicator trends of priority fisheries
text:
A fishery system is usually intersected in three perspectives—biological, harvesting and management (Figure 6.1). The biological perspective is identified by a breeding population. The harvesting business perspective is identified by fleets using comparable technologies and serving similar markets. The management perspective is identified by a common set of rules for access and harvest.
For sustainable fishery the three perspective must intersect. Several indicators are used to assess the sustainability of the fishery. In this chapter we discuss some indicators that we chose to assess the sustainability of priority fishery in the study area. Based on available data, catch rate, the composition of fished species and total fish production were chosen as metric to evaluate the health of the fishery in Kibiti, Mafia and Kilwa Seascape (Figure 6.2).
Several achieved fisheries data from government, NGO and, academia and research institutes was used to evaluate the effectiveness of management systems and help answer what works. What works best for fisheries? What works best for economic returns, business and employment? What works best for the community?

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text: Quarto is the successor to R Markdown, however it is relatively new and many people still use R Markdown. For the most part, the aspects covered in ?sec-reproducible-workflows are very similar in both Quarto and R Markdown. However, in this appendix we provide an equivalent for R Markdown, for the guidance provided for Quarto.

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.1 Getting started
R Markdown integrates code and natural language in a way that is called ‘literate programming’ (Knuth1984?). R Markdown is a mark-up language similar to HyperText Markup Language (HTML) or LaTeX, in comparison to a ‘What You See Is What You Get’ (WYSIWYG) language, such as Microsoft Word. This means that all the aspects are consistent, for instance, all top-level heading will look the same. But, it means that we must use symbols to designate how we would like certain aspects to appear. And it is only when we build the mark-up that we get to see what it looks like.
R Markdown is a variant of Markdown that is specifically designed to allow R code chunks to be included. One advantage is that we can get a ‘live’ document in which code executes and then forms part of the document. Another advantage of R Markdown is that very similar code can compile into a variety of documents, including html pages and PDFs. R Markdown also has default options set up for including a title, author, and date sections. One disadvantage is that it can take a while for a document to compile because all the code needs to run. (rmarkdownforscientists?) is especially useful for instructions on how to achieve specific outcomes with R Markdown.
We can create a new R Markdown document within RStudio (‘File’ -> ‘New File’ -> ‘R Markdown Document’).

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.2 Essential commands
Essential markdown commands include those for emphasis, headers, lists, links, and images. A reminder of these is included in RStudio (‘Help’ -> ‘Markdown Quick Reference’).

Emphasis: *italic*, **bold**
Headers (these go on their own line with a blank line before and after): # First level header, ## Second level header, ## Third level header
Unordered list, with sub-lists:

* Item 1
* Item 2
    + Item 2a
    + Item 2b

Ordered list, with sub-lists:

1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
    + Item 3a
    + Item 3b

URLs can be added by including an address because it will auto-link: https://www.tellingstorieswithdata.com, or by linking some text [the address of this book](https://www.tellingstorieswithdata.com) results in the address of this book.
A paragraph is created by leaving a blank line.

A paragraph about some idea, nicely spaced from the following paragraph.

Another paragraph about another idea, nicely spaced from the earlier paragraph.
Once we have added some aspects, then we may want to see the actual document. To build the document click ‘Knit’.

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.3 R chunks
We can include code for R and many other languages in code chunks within an R Markdown document. Then when we knit the document, the code will run and be included in the document.
To create an R chunk, we start with three backticks and then within curly braces we tell R Markdown that this is an R chunk. Anything inside this chunk will be considered R code and run as such. For instance, we could load the tidyverse and AER and make a graph of the number of times a survey respondent visited the doctor in the past two weeks.



The output of that code is Figure @ref(fig:doctervisits).





Number of illnesses in the past two weeks, based on the 1977–1978 Australian Health Survey




There are various evaluation options that are available in chunks. We include these by putting a comma after r and then specifying any options before the closing curly brace. Helpful options include:

echo = FALSE: run the code and include the output, but do not print the code in the document.
include = FALSE: run the code but do not output anything and do not print the code in the document.
eval = FALSE: do not run the code, and hence do not include the outputs, but do print the code in the document.
warning = FALSE: do not display warnings.
message = FALSE: do not display messages.

For instance, we could include the output, but not the code, and suppress any warnings.



It is important to leave a blank line on either side of an R chunk, otherwise it may not run properly.



It is also important that the R Markdown document itself loads any datasets that are needed. It is not enough that they are in the environment. This is because the R Markdown document evaluates the code in the document when it is built, not necessarily the environment.

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.4 Abstracts and PDF outputs
An abstract is a short summary of the paper. In the default preamble, we can add a section for an abstract. Similarly, we can change the output from html_document to pdf_document to produce a PDF. This uses LaTeX in the background and may require the installation of supporting packages.
---
title: My document
author: Rohan Alexander
date: 1 January 2022
output: pdf_document
abstract: "This is my abstract."
---

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.5 References
We can include references by specifying a BibTeX file in the preamble and then calling it within the text, as needed.
---
title: My document
author: Rohan Alexander
date: 1 January 2022
output: pdf_document
abstract: "This is my abstract."
bibliography: bibliography.bib
---
We would need to make a separate file called ‘bibliography.bib’ and save it next to the R Markdown file. In the BibTeX file we need an entry for the item that is to be referenced. For instance, the citation for R can be obtained with citation() and this can be added to the ‘bibliography.bib’ file. Similarly, the citation for a package can be found by including the package name, for instance citation('tidyverse'). It can be helpful to use Google Scholar, or doi2bib, to get citations for books or articles.
@Manual{,
    title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing},
    author = {{R Core Team}},
    organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing},
    address = {Vienna, Austria},
    year = {2021},
    url = {https://www.R-project.org/},
  }
@Article{,
    title = {Welcome to the {tidyverse}},
    author = {Hadley Wickham and Mara Averick and Jennifer Bryan and Winston Chang and Lucy D'Agostino McGowan and Romain François and Garrett Grolemund and Alex Hayes and Lionel Henry and Jim Hester and Max Kuhn and Thomas Lin Pedersen and Evan Miller and Stephan Milton Bache and Kirill Müller and Jeroen Ooms and David Robinson and Dana Paige Seidel and Vitalie Spinu and Kohske Takahashi and Davis Vaughan and Claus Wilke and Kara Woo and Hiroaki Yutani},
    year = {2019},
    journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},
    volume = {4},
    number = {43},
    pages = {1686},
    doi = {10.21105/joss.01686},
  }
We need to create a unique key that we use to refer to this item in the text. This can be anything, provided it is unique, but meaningful ones can be easier to remember, for instance ‘citeR’.
@Manual{citeR,
    title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing},
    author = {{R Core Team}},
    organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing},
    address = {Vienna, Austria},
    year = {2021},
    url = {https://www.R-project.org/},
  }
@Article{tidyverse,
    title = {Welcome to the {tidyverse}},
    author = {Hadley Wickham and Mara Averick and Jennifer Bryan and Winston Chang and Lucy D'Agostino McGowan and Romain François and Garrett Grolemund and Alex Hayes and Lionel Henry and Jim Hester and Max Kuhn and Thomas Lin Pedersen and Evan Miller and Stephan Milton Bache and Kirill Müller and Jeroen Ooms and David Robinson and Dana Paige Seidel and Vitalie Spinu and Kohske Takahashi and Davis Vaughan and Claus Wilke and Kara Woo and Hiroaki Yutani},
    year = {2019},
    journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},
    volume = {4},
    number = {43},
    pages = {1686},
    doi = {10.21105/joss.01686},
  }
To cite R in the R Markdown document we include @citeR, which would put the brackets around the year, like this: (citeR?) or [@citeR], which would put the brackets around the whole thing, like this: (tidyverse?).
The reference list at the end of the paper is automatically built based on calling the BibTeX file and including the references in the paper. At the end of the R Markdown document, including a heading ‘# References’ and the actual citations will be included after that. When the R Markdown file is built, R Markdown sees these in the content, goes to BibTeX to get the reference details that it needs, builds the reference list, and then adds it to the end of the output.

title: Appendix A — R Markdown
text:
A.6 Cross-references
It can be useful to cross-reference figures, tables, and equations. This makes it easier to refer to them in the text. To do this for a figure we refer to the name of the R chunk that creates or contains the figure. For instance, (Figure \@ref(fig:uniquename)) will produce: (Figure @ref(fig:uniquename)) as the name of the R chunk is uniquename. We also need to add ‘fig’ in front of the chunk name so that R Markdown knows that this is a figure. We then include a ‘fig.cap’ in the R chunk that specifies a caption.
```{r uniquename, fig.cap = "Number of illnesses in the past two weeks, based on the 1977--1978 Australian Health Survey", echo = TRUE}

library(tidyverse)
library(AER)

data("DoctorVisits", package = "AER")

DoctorVisits |>
  ggplot(aes(x = illness)) +
  geom_histogram(stat = "count")




Number of illnesses in the past two weeks, based on the 1977–1978 Australian Health Survey




We can take a similar, but slightly different, approach to cross-reference tables. For instance, (Table \@ref(tab:docvisittable)) will produce: (Table A.1). In this case we specify ‘tab’ before the unique reference to the table, so that R Markdown knows that it is a table. For tables we need to include the caption in the main content, as a ‘caption’, rather than in a ‘fig.cap’ chunk option as is the case for figures.

Finally, we can also cross-reference equations. To that we need to add a tag (\#eq:macroidentity) which we then reference. For instance, use Equation \@ref(eq:macroidentity). to produce Equation @ref(eq:macroidentity).
\begin{equation}
Y = C + I + G + (X - M) (\#eq:macroidentity)
\end{equation}
\[\begin{equation}
Y = C + I + G + (X - M) (\#eq:macroidentity)
\end{equation}\]
When using cross-references, it is important that the R chunks have simple labels. In general, try to keep the names simple but unique, and if possible, avoid punctuation and stick to letters. Do not use underbars in the labels because that will cause an error.
